newsitem.title: GERMANY: German FDP leader warns of dangers if EMU fails.
newsitem.headline: German FDP leader warns of dangers if EMU fails.

text.p: The leader of Germany's liberal Free Democrats (FDP), junior partners in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, warned on Friday of the dangers of failing to realise European monetary union.

Wolfgang Gerhardt told a party congress that a failure of the single currency project would lead to a relaxation of monetary and fiscal discipline, push up the value of the mark and harm the competitiveness of German firms.

"The danger cannot be ruled out that the single European market would erode, governments would no longer be able to resist the temptation of competitive devaluations," Gerhardt told delegates in the central spa town of Wiesbaden.
Gerhardt said he was confident Germany would meet the criteria for monetary union and that the euro would be a strong and stable currency which would boost the German economy.
"I am convinced we can't forge our future on our own as an island of stability," he said to loud applause from delegates.
He also offered strong support to Finance Minister Theo Waigel's plan to revalue the Bundesbank's gold reserves in the run-up to the single currency.

"The Bundesbank will sell not one ounce of gold and no currency reserves. A burden of the capital markets is therefore ruled out and an important political goal, the borrowing convergence criterion for the currency union, will be met."
Like all major German political parties, the FDP is overwhelmingly pro-European but some members at the congress called for a referendum or at least a party membership survey on the single currency.

One delegate, noting that opinion polls showed around two thirds of German voters rejected the single currency, said a party which had the courage to support the euro must also have the courage to put the issue to a vote.
Former economics minister Juergen Moellemann said it was important the party debated the subject of monetary union.

"It is strange the way the subject is a taboo for all parties," Moellemann told the Koelner Stadt-Anzeiger newspaper. "The acceptance of the new currency, in the population as a whole and especially among FDP voters, is very limited."
